GLQuote: For the scripture says
OccurrenceNote: Here the **scripture** is personified as if God were talking to Pharaoh. Alternate translation: “For the scripture records that God said” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

GLQuote: I … my
OccurrenceNote: Here the pronouns **I** and **my** refer to God as the speaker.

GLQuote: you
OccurrenceNote: Here, **you** is singular and refers to Pharaoh. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])

GLQuote: I raised you up
OccurrenceNote: Here, **raised** is an idiom for causing something to be what it is. Alternate translation: “I made you the powerful man that you are” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

GLQuote: so that my name might be proclaimed
OccurrenceNote: You can translate this in an active form. Alternate translation: “so that people might proclaim my name” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

GLQuote: my name
OccurrenceNote: Here, **name** is a metonym that could refer to: (1) God in all of his being. Alternate translation: “who I am” (2) God’s reputation. Alternate translation: “how great I am” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

GLQuote: in all the earth
OccurrenceNote: “wherever there are people” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])

GLQuote: whom he wishes, he makes stubborn
OccurrenceNote: God makes stubborn whoever he wishes to make stubborn.

GLQuote: You will say then to me
OccurrenceNote: Paul is talking to the critics of his teaching as though he were only talking to one person. You may need to use the plural here. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])

OrigQuote: τί οὖν ἔτι μέμφεται? τῷ γὰρ βουλήματι αὐτοῦ, τίς ἀνθέστηκεν?
GLQuote: Why does he still find fault? For who has ever withstood his will?
OccurrenceNote: These rhetorical questions are complaints against God. You can translate them as strong statements. Alternate translation: “He should not find fault with us. No one has ever been able to withstand his will.” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

GLQuote: he … his
OccurrenceNote: The words **he** and **his** here refer to God.

GLQuote: has … withstood his will
OccurrenceNote: Alternate translation: “who has ever stopped him from doing what he wanted to do”

OrigQuote: μὴ ἐρεῖ τὸ πλάσμα, τῷ πλάσαντι, τί με ἐποίησας οὕτως?
GLQuote: Will what has been molded say to the one who molds it, “Why … way?”
OccurrenceNote: Paul uses the potter’s right to make any kind of container he wants from the clay as a metaphor for the creator’s right to do whatever he wants with his creation. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

OrigQuote: μὴ ἐρεῖ τὸ πλάσμα, τῷ πλάσαντι, τί με ἐποίησας οὕτως?
OccurrenceNote: Paul asks questions to emphasize his point. You can translate this as a strong statement. Alternate translation: “What a person has molded should never say to the one who molds it, ‘Why did you make me this way?’!” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

GLQuote: Why did you make me this way?
OccurrenceNote: This question is a rebuke and can be translated as a strong statement. Alternate translation: “You should not have made me this way!” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

OrigQuote: ἢ οὐκ ἔχει ἐξουσίαν ὁ κεραμεὺς τοῦ πηλοῦ, ἐκ τοῦ αὐτοῦ φυράματος ποιῆσαι ὃ μὲν εἰς τιμὴν σκεῦος, ὃ δὲ εἰς ἀτιμίαν?
GLQuote: Does the potter not have the right … for daily use?
OccurrenceNote: This rhetorical question is a rebuke. Alternate translation: “The potter certainly has the right over the clay to make from the same lump a container for special occasions, but another for daily use.” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

GLQuote: containers of wrath
OccurrenceNote: Paul speaks of people as if they were **containers**. Alternate translation: “people who deserve wrath” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

GLQuote: he … his
OccurrenceNote: The pronouns **he** and **his** here refer to God.

GLQuote: containers of mercy
OccurrenceNote: Paul speaks of people as if they were **containers**. Alternate translation: “people who deserve mercy” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

OrigQuote: τὸν πλοῦτον τῆς δόξης αὐτοῦ ἐπὶ
GLQuote: the riches of his glory upon
OccurrenceNote: Paul compares God’s wonderful actions here to great **riches**. Alternate translation: “his glory, which is of great value, upon” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

GLQuote: which he had previously prepared for glory
OccurrenceNote: Here, **glory** refers to life in heaven with God. Alternate translation: “whom he prepared ahead of time in order that they might live with him” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

GLQuote: also for us
OccurrenceNote: The pronoun **us** here refers to Paul and fellow believers. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-exclusive]])

GLQuote: called
OccurrenceNote: Here, **called** means God has appointed or chosen people to be his children, to be his servants and proclaimers of his message of salvation through Jesus.

GLQuote: Connecting Statement:
OccurrenceNote: In this section Paul explains how Israel’s unbelief as a nation was told ahead of time by the prophet Hosea.

OrigQuote: ὡς καὶ ἐν τῷ Ὡσηὲ λέγει
GLQuote: As he says also in Hosea
OccurrenceNote: Here, **he** refers to God. Alternate translation: “As God says also in the book that Hosea wrote” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

GLQuote: Hosea
OccurrenceNote: **Hosea** was an Old Testament prophet. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

OrigQuote: καλέσω τὸν οὐ λαόν μου, λαόν μου
GLQuote: I will call my people who were not my people
OccurrenceNote: Alternate translation: “I will choose for my people those who were not my people”

GLQuote: her beloved who was not beloved
OccurrenceNote: Here, **the one** refers to Hosea’s wife, Gomer, who represents the nation of Israel. You can translate this in an active form. Alternate translation: “I will choose her whom I did not love to be one whom I love” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

GLQuote: sons of the living God
OccurrenceNote: The word **living** may refer to the fact that God is the only true God, and not like the false idols. Alternate translation: “children of the true God”

GLQuote: cries out
OccurrenceNote: Alternate translation: “calls out”

GLQuote: as the sand of the sea
OccurrenceNote: Here Paul compares the number of the people of Israel to the number of grains of **sand** in the **sea**. Alternate translation: “too many to count” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

GLQuote: will be saved
OccurrenceNote: Paul uses the word **saved** in a spiritual sense. If God saves a person, it means that through believing in Jesus’ death on the cross, God has forgiven him and rescued him from being punished for his sin. You can translate this in an active form. Alternate translation: “God will save” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

GLQuote: the Lord will carry out his sentence on the earth
OccurrenceNote: Here, **word** refers to how he has decided to punish people. Alternate translation: “the Lord will punish people on the earth according to how he has said”

GLQuote: us … we
OccurrenceNote: Here the pronouns **us** and **we** refer to Isaiah and those to whom he spoke. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-exclusive]])

OrigQuote: ὡς Σόδομα ἂν ἐγενήθημεν, καὶ ὡς Γόμορρα ἂν ὡμοιώθημεν
GLQuote: we would be like Sodom, and we would have become like Gomorrah
OccurrenceNote: God killed all of the people of Sodom and Gomorrah because of their sin. Alternate translation: “we all would have been destroyed like the people of Sodom and Gomorrah” or “God would have destroyed all of us, like he destroyed the cities of Sodom and Gommorah” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

GLQuote: What will we say then?
OccurrenceNote: Paul uses this question to get the attention of his readers. Alternate translation: “This is what we must say.” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

GLQuote: That the Gentiles
OccurrenceNote: Alternate translation: “We will say that the Gentiles”

GLQuote: who were not pursuing righteousness
OccurrenceNote: Alternate translation: “who were not trying to please God”

GLQuote: the righteousness by faith
OccurrenceNote: Here, **by faith** refers to placing one’s trust in Christ. You can make this explicit in your translation. Alternate translation: “because God made them right with him when they trusted in Christ” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

GLQuote: did not arrive at it
OccurrenceNote: This means that the Israelites could not please God by trying to keep **the law**. You can make this explicit in your translation. Alternate translation: “were not able to please God by keeping the law because they could not keep it” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

GLQuote: Why not?
OccurrenceNote: This is an ellipsis. You can include the implied words in your translation. Alternate translation: “Why could they not attain righteousness?” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
Paul asks this question to get the attention of his readers. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

GLQuote: by works
OccurrenceNote: This refers to things that people do to try to please God. You can make this explicit in your translation. Alternate translation: “by trying to do things that would please God” or “by keeping the Law” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

GLQuote: as it has been written
OccurrenceNote: You can indicate that Isaiah wrote this. Alternate translation: “just as it has been written by Isaiah the prophet” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
You can translate this in an active form. Alternate translation: “as Isaiah the prophet wrote” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

GLQuote: in Zion
OccurrenceNote: Here, **Zion** is a metonym that represents Israel. Alternate translation: “in Israel” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

GLQuote: stone of stumbling and a rock of offense
OccurrenceNote: Both of these phrases mean basically the same thing. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])

These phrases are metaphors that refer to Jesus and his death on the cross. It was as if the people stumbled over a stone because they were disgusted when they considered Jesus’ death on the cross. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

GLQuote: believes in it
OccurrenceNote: Because the stone stands for a person, you may need to translate this as “who believes in him.”

# Romans 10 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

6. God’s plan for Israel (9:1–11:36)
* Paul’s sorrow for Israel’s unbelief (9:1–5)
* God chooses whom he wants to choose (9:6–13)
* God shows mercy on whom he wants to show mercy (9:14–18)
* No one can question God’s choice (9:19–33)
* Israel’s false righteousness (10:1–4)
* Salvation is available to everyone (10:5–21)

Some translations set prose quotations from the Old Testament farther to the right on the page than the rest of the text. The ULT does this with the quoted words in verse 8.

Some translations set each line of poetry farther to the right than the rest of the text to make it easier to read. The ULT does this with verses 18-20 of this chapter, which are words from the Old Testament.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### God’s righteousness

Paul teaches here that while many Jews earnestly tried to be righteous, they did not succeed. We cannot earn God’s righteousness. God gives us Jesus’ righteousness when we believe in him. (See: [[rc://en/tw/dict/bible/kt/righteous]] and [[rc://en/tw/dict/bible/kt/faith]])

## Important figures of speech in this chapter

### Rhetorical questions

Paul uses many rhetorical questions in this chapter. He does this to convince his readers that God does not save only the Hebrew people, so Christians must be ready to go and share the gospel with the whole world. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://en/tw/dict/bible/kt/save]])

## Other possible translation difficulties in this chapter

### “I will provoke you to jealousy by what is not a nation”

Paul uses this prophecy to explain that God will use the church to make the Hebrew people jealous. This is so they will seek God and believe the gospel. (See: [[rc://en/tw/dict/bible/kt/prophet]] and [[rc://en/tw/dict/bible/kt/jealous]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

GLQuote: Connecting Statement:
OccurrenceNote: Paul continues stating his desire for Israel to believe but emphasizes that both those who are Jews as well as everyone else can only be saved by faith in Jesus.

GLQuote: Brothers
OccurrenceNote: Here, **brothers** refers to fellow Christians, including both men and women.

OrigQuote: ἡ μὲν εὐδοκία τῆς ἐμῆς καρδίας
GLQuote: my heart’s desire
OccurrenceNote: Here, **heart** is a metonym for a person’s emotions or inner being. Alternate translation: “my greatest desire” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

GLQuote: is for them, for their salvation
OccurrenceNote: Alternate translation: “is that God will save the Jews”

GLQuote: I testify about them
OccurrenceNote: Alternate translation: “I declare truthfully about them”

OrigQuote: ἀγνοοῦντες γὰρ τὴν τοῦ Θεοῦ δικαιοσύνην
GLQuote: For they do not know of God’s righteousness
OccurrenceNote: Here, **righteousness** refers to the way God puts people right with himself. You can make this explicit in the translation. Alternate translation: “For they do not know how God puts people right with himself” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

OrigQuote: τῇ δικαιοσύνῃ τοῦ Θεοῦ οὐχ ὑπετάγησαν
GLQuote: They did not submit to the righteousness of God
OccurrenceNote: Alternate translation: “they did not accept God’s way of putting people right with himself”

GLQuote: For Christ is the fulfillment of the law
OccurrenceNote: Alternate translation: “For Christ completely fulfilled the law”

GLQuote: for righteousness for everyone who believes
OccurrenceNote: Here, **believes** means “trusts.” Alternate translation: “in order that he may make everyone who trusts in him right before God” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

GLQuote: the righteousness that comes from the law
OccurrenceNote: Alternate translation: “how the law makes a person right before God”

OrigQuote: ὅτι ὁ ποιήσας αὐτὰ ἄνθρωπος, ζήσεται ἐν αὐτῇ
GLQuote: The man who does the righteousness of the law will live by this righteousness
OccurrenceNote: In order to be made right with God through the law, a person would have to keep the law perfectly, which is not possible. Alternate translation: “The person who perfectly obeys the law will live because the law will make him right before God” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

GLQuote: will live
OccurrenceNote: Here, **will live** could refer to: (1) eternal life. (2) mortal life in fellowship with God.

OrigQuote: ἡ δὲ ἐκ πίστεως δικαιοσύνη οὕτως λέγει
GLQuote: But the righteousness that comes from faith says this
OccurrenceNote: Here, **righteousness** is described as a person who can speak. Alternate translation: “But Moses writes this about how faith makes a person right before God” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

OrigQuote: μὴ εἴπῃς ἐν τῇ καρδίᾳ σου
GLQuote: Do not say in your heart
OccurrenceNote: Moses was addressing the people as if he were speaking to only one person. The pronoun **your** is singular. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])

OrigQuote: μὴ εἴπῃς ἐν τῇ καρδίᾳ σου
OccurrenceNote: Here, **heart** is a metonym for a person’s mind or inner being. Alternate translation: “Do not say to yourself” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

GLQuote: Who will ascend into heaven?
OccurrenceNote: Moses uses a question to teach his audience. His previous instruction of, “Do not say” requires a negative answer to this question. You can translate this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “No one is able to go up to heaven” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

GLQuote: that is, to bring Christ down
OccurrenceNote: Alternate translation: “in order that they might have Christ come down to earth”

GLQuote: Who will descend into the abyss
OccurrenceNote: Moses uses a question to teach his audience. His previous instruction of, “Do not say” requires a negative answer to this question. You can translate this as a statement. Alternate translation: “No person can go down and enter the place where the spirits of dead persons are” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

GLQuote: from the dead
OccurrenceNote: From among all those who have died. This expression describes all **dead** people together in the underworld.

GLQuote: dead
OccurrenceNote: Here, **the dead** speaks of physical death.

GLQuote: But what does it say?
OccurrenceNote: The word **it** refers to “the righteousness” of [Romans 10:6](../10/06.md). Here Paul describes righteousness as a person who can speak. Alternate translation: “But this is what Moses says?” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
Paul uses a question to emphasize the answer he is about to give. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

GLQuote: The word is near you
OccurrenceNote: Paul speaks of God’s word as if it were a person who can move. Alternate translation: “You have heard the message” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

OrigQuote: ἐγγύς σου τὸ ῥῆμά ἐστιν, ἐν τῷ στόματί σου, καὶ ἐν τῇ καρδίᾳ σου
GLQuote: The word is … in your mouth
OccurrenceNote: The word **mouth** is a metonym that refers to what a person says. Alternate translation: “You can hear and know how to speak and think about God’s message” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

GLQuote: The word is … in your heart
OccurrenceNote: The phrase **in your heart** is metonym that refers to what a person thinks and believes. Alternate translation: “and you know what it means” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

GLQuote: the word of faith
OccurrenceNote: Alternate translation: “God’s message that tells us that we must believe in him”

OrigQuote: ἐὰν ὁμολογήσῃς ἐν τῷ στόματί σου, Κύριον Ἰησοῦν
GLQuote: if with your mouth you confess Jesus as Lord
OccurrenceNote: Alternate translation: “if you verbally confess that Jesus is Lord”

GLQuote: believe in your heart
OccurrenceNote: Here, **heart** is a metonym for a person’s mind or inner person. Alternate translation: “believe in your mind” or “truly believe” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

GLQuote: raised him from the dead
OccurrenceNote: Here, **raised** here is an idiom for “caused to live again.” Alternate translation: “caused him to live again” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

GLQuote: you will be saved
OccurrenceNote: You can translate this in an active form. Alternate translation: “God will save you” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

OrigQuote: καρδίᾳ γὰρ πιστεύεται εἰς δικαιοσύνην, στόματι δὲ ὁμολογεῖται εἰς σωτηρίαν
GLQuote: For with the heart one believes unto righteousness, and with the mouth one confesses unto salvation
OccurrenceNote: Here, **heart** is a metonym that represents the mind or will. Alternate translation: “For it is with the mind that a person trusts and is right before God, and it is with the mouth that a person confesses and God saves him” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

GLQuote: with the mouth
OccurrenceNote: Here, **mouth** is a synecdoche that represents a person’s capacity to speak. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

GLQuote: For scripture says
OccurrenceNote: Paul speaks of the scripture as if it were alive and had a voice. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
You can make explicit who wrote the scripture that Paul uses here. Alternate translation: “For Isaiah wrote in the scriptures” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

OrigQuote: πᾶς ὁ πιστεύων ἐπ’ αὐτῷ οὐ καταισχυνθήσεται
GLQuote: Everyone who believes on him will not be put to shame
OccurrenceNote: This is equivalent to: “Everyone who does not believe will be shamed.” The negative is used here for emphasis. You can translate this in an active form. Alternate translation: “God will honor everyone who believes in him” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

OrigQuote: οὐ γάρ ἐστιν διαστολὴ Ἰουδαίου τε καὶ Ἕλληνος
GLQuote: For there is no difference between Jew and Greek
OccurrenceNote: Paul implies that God will treat all people the same. You can make this explicit in your translation. Alternate translation: “In this way, God treats the Jews and the non-Jews the same” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

OrigQuote: πλουτῶν εἰς πάντας τοὺς ἐπικαλουμένους αὐτόν
GLQuote: he is rich to all who call upon him
OccurrenceNote: Here, **being rich** means that God blesses richly. You can make this explicit in your translation. Alternate translation: “and he richly blesses all who trust in him” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

OrigQuote: πᾶς γὰρ ὃς ἂν ἐπικαλέσηται τὸ ὄνομα Κυρίου, σωθήσεται
GLQuote: For everyone who calls on the name of the Lord will be saved
OccurrenceNote: Here the word **name** is a metonym for Jesus. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

OrigQuote: πᾶς γὰρ ὃς ἂν ἐπικαλέσηται τὸ ὄνομα Κυρίου, σωθήσεται
OccurrenceNote: You can translate this in an active form. Alternate translation: “For the Lord will save everyone who trusts in him” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

OrigQuote: πῶς οὖν ἐπικαλέσωνται εἰς ὃν οὐκ ἐπίστευσαν?
GLQuote: How then can they call on him in whom they have not believed?
OccurrenceNote: Paul uses a question to emphasize the importance of taking the good news of Christ to those who have not heard. The word **they** refers to those who do not yet belong to God. Alternate translation: “Those who do not believe in God cannot call on him!” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

GLQuote: How can they believe in him of whom they have not heard?
OccurrenceNote: Paul uses another question for the same reason. Alternate translation: “they cannot believe in him if they have not heard his message!” or “they cannot believe in him if they have not heard the message about him!” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

GLQuote: believe in
OccurrenceNote: Here this means to acknowledge that what that person has said is true.

GLQuote: How can they hear without a preacher?
OccurrenceNote: Paul uses another question for the same reason. Alternate translation: “they cannot hear the message if someone does not tell them!” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

OrigQuote: ὡς ὡραῖοι οἱ πόδες τῶν εὐαγγελιζομένων τὰ ἀγαθά!
GLQuote: How beautiful are the feet of those who proclaim good news
OccurrenceNote: Paul uses **feet** to represent those who travel and bring the message to those who have not heard it. Alternate translation: “It is wonderful when messengers come and tell us the good news” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

GLQuote: not all of them obeyed
OccurrenceNote: Here, **them** refers to the Jews. “not all of the Jews obeyed”

OrigQuote: Κύριε, τίς ἐπίστευσεν τῇ ἀκοῇ ἡμῶν?
GLQuote: Lord, who has believed our message?
OccurrenceNote: Paul is using this question to emphasize that Isaiah prophesied in the Scriptures that many Jews would not believe in Jesus. You can translate this as a statement. Alternate translation: “Lord, so many of them do not believe our message.” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

GLQuote: our message
OccurrenceNote: Here, **our** refers to God and Isaiah.

GLQuote: faith comes from hearing
OccurrenceNote: Here, **faith** refers to “believing in Christ”

GLQuote: hearing by the word of Christ
OccurrenceNote: Alternate translation: “hearing by listening to the message about Christ”

OrigQuote: ἀλλὰ λέγω, μὴ οὐκ ἤκουσαν? μενοῦνγε
GLQuote: But I say, “Did they not hear?” Yes, most certainly
OccurrenceNote: Paul uses a question for emphasis. You can translate this as a statement. Alternate translation: “But, I say the Jews certainly have heard the message about Christ” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

OrigQuote: εἰς πᾶσαν τὴν γῆν, ἐξῆλθεν ὁ φθόγγος αὐτῶν; καὶ εἰς τὰ πέρατα τῆς οἰκουμένης, τὰ ῥήματα αὐτῶν
GLQuote: Their sound has gone out into all the earth, and their words to the ends of the world.
OccurrenceNote: Both of these statements mean basically the same thing and Paul uses them for emphasis. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

OrigQuote: εἰς πᾶσαν τὴν γῆν, ἐξῆλθεν ὁ φθόγγος αὐτῶν; καὶ εἰς τὰ πέρατα τῆς οἰκουμένης, τὰ ῥήματα αὐτῶν
OccurrenceNote: The word **their** refers to the sun, moon, and stars. Here they are described as human messengers that tell people about God. This refers to how their existence shows God’s power and glory. Alternate translation: “The sun, moon, and the stars are proof of God’s power and glory, and everyone in the world sees them and knows the truth about God.” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

OrigQuote: εἰς πᾶσαν τὴν γῆν, ἐξῆλθεν ὁ φθόγγος αὐτῶν; καὶ εἰς τὰ πέρατα τῆς οἰκουμένης, τὰ ῥήματα αὐτῶν
OccurrenceNote: You can make explicit that Paul is quoting Scripture here. Alternate translation: “As the Scriptures record, ‘The sun, moon, and the stars are proof of God’s power and glory, and everyone in the world sees them and knows the truth about God.’” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

# Romans 11 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

6. God’s plan for Israel (9:1–11:36)
* Paul’s sorrow for Israel’s unbelief (9:1–5)
* God chooses whom he wants to choose (9:6–13)
* God shows mercy on whom he wants to show mercy (9:14–18)
* No one can question God’s choice (9:19–33)
* Israel’s false righteousness (10:1–4)
* Salvation is available to everyone (10:5–21)
* Israel has a faithful remnant (11:1–10)
* Israel’s unbelief resulted in non-Jews’ belief (11:11–24)
* God will save Israel (11:15–32)
* Praise for God’s wisdom (11:33–11:36)

Some translations set each line of poetry farther to the right than the rest of the text to make it easier to read. The ULT does this with verses 9-10, 26-27, and 34-35, which are words from the Old Testament.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Grafting

Paul uses the image of “grafting” to refer to the place of the Gentiles and Jews in the plans of God. Making one plant to be permanently part of another plant is called “grafting.” Paul uses the picture of God grafting the Gentiles as a wild branch into his saving plans. But God has not forgotten about the Jews, who are spoken of as the natural plant. God will also save Jews who believe in Jesus.

## Other possible translation difficulties in this chapter

### “Did God reject his people? May it never be”

Whether Israel (the physical descendants of Abraham, Isaac and Jacob) has a future in the plans of God, or if they have been replaced in the plans of God by the church, is a major theological issue in Chapters 9-11. This phrase is an important part of this section of Romans. It seems to indicate that Israel remains distinct from the church. Not all scholars arrive at this conclusion. Despite their currently rejecting Jesus as their Messiah, Israel has not exhausted the grace and mercy of God. (See: [[rc://en/tw/dict/bible/kt/christ]] and [[rc://en/tw/dict/bible/kt/grace]] and [[rc://en/tw/dict/bible/kt/mercy]])

# Romans 12 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

7. Instructions for living as Christians (12:1–15:13)
* How to act toward God (12:1–2)
* How to serve the church (12:3–8)
* How to act toward other Christians (12:9–13)
* How to act toward unbelievers (12:14–21)
* How to act toward government (13:1–7)
* How to act toward other people (13:8–10)
* Act as if the end is near (13:11–14)
* Do not judge other Christians (14:1–12)
* Do not tempt other Christians to sin (14:13–23)
* Be united with other Christians (15:1–13)

Some translations set each line of poetry farther to the right than the rest of the text to make it easier to read. The ULT does this with the words of verse 20, which are from the Old Testament.

Many scholars believe Paul uses the word **therefore** in [Romans 12:1](../rom/12/01.md) to refer back to all of Chapters 1-11. Having carefully explained the Christian gospel, Paul now explains how Christians should live in light of these great truths. Chapters 12-16 focus on living out one’s Christian faith. Paul uses many different commands in these chapters to give these practical instructions. (See: [[rc://en/tw/dict/bible/kt/faith]])

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Christian living

Under the law of Moses, people were required to offer temple sacrifices of animals or grain. Now Christians are required to live their lives as a type of sacrifice to God. Physical sacrifices are no longer required. (See: [[rc://en/tw/dict/bible/kt/lawofmoses]])

## Important figures of speech in this chapter

### Body of Christ

The body of Christ is an important metaphor or image used in Scripture to refer to the church. Each church member plays a unique and important function. Christians need each other. (See: [[rc://en/tw/dict/bible/kt/body]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

# Romans 13 General Notes

## Structure and formatting


7. Instructions for living as Christians (12:1–15:13)
* How to act toward God (12:1–2)
* How to serve the church (12:3–8)
* How to act toward other Christians (12:9–13)
* How to act toward unbelievers (12:14–21)
* How to act toward government (13:1–7)
* How to act toward other people (13:8–10)
* Act as if the end is near (13:11–14)

In the first part of this chapter, Paul teaches Christians to obey rulers who govern them. At that time, ungodly Roman rulers governed the land. (See: [[rc://en/tw/dict/bible/kt/godly]])

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Ungodly rulers

When Paul teaches about obeying rulers, some readers will find this difficult to understand, especially in places where rulers persecute the church. Christians must obey their rulers as well as obey God, unless the rulers do not allow Christians to do something God explicitly commands them to do. There are times when a believer must submit to these rulers and suffer at their hands. Christians understand that this world is temporary and they will ultimately be with God forever. (See: [[rc://en/tw/dict/bible/kt/eternity]])

## Other possible translation difficulties in this chapter

### Flesh

This is a complex issue. “Flesh” is possibly a metaphor for our sinful nature. Paul is not teaching that our physical bodies are sinful. Paul appears to be teaching that as long as Christians are alive (“in the flesh”), we will continue to sin. But our new nature will be fighting against our old nature. (See: [[rc://en/tw/dict/bible/kt/flesh]] and [[rc://en/tw/dict/bible/kt/sin]])

# Romans 14 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

7. Instructions for living as Christians (12:1–15:13)
* How to act toward God (12:1–2)
* How to serve the church (12:3–8)
* How to act toward other Christians (12:9–13)
* How to act toward unbelievers (12:14–21)
* How to act toward government (13:1–7)
* How to act toward other people (13:8–10)
* Act as if the end is near (13:11–14)
* Do not judge other Christians (14:1–12)
* Do not tempt other Christians to sin (14:13–23)

Some translations set each line of poetry farther to the right than the rest of the text to make it easier to read. The ULT does this with verse 11 of this chapter, which Paul quotes from the Old Testament.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Weak in faith

Paul teaches that Christians can have real faith and at the same time be “weak in faith” in a given situation. This describes Christians whose faith is immature, not strong, or misunderstood. (See: [[rc://en/tw/dict/bible/kt/faith]])

### Dietary restrictions

Many religions in the ancient Near East restricted what was eaten. Christians have freedom to eat what they want. But they need to use this freedom wisely, in a way that honors the Lord and does not cause others to sin. (See: [[rc://en/tw/dict/bible/kt/sin]])

### The judgment seat of God

The judgment seat of God or Christ represents a time when all people, including Christians, will be held accountable for the way they lived their lives.

# Romans 15 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

7. Instructions for living as Christians (12:1–15:13)
* How to act toward God (12:1–2)
* How to serve the church (12:3–8)
* How to act toward other Christians (12:9–13)
* How to act toward unbelievers (12:14–21)
* How to act toward government (13:1–7)
* How to act toward other people (13:8–10)
* Act as if the end is near (13:11–14)
* Do not judge other Christians (14:1–12)
* Do not tempt other Christians to sin (14:13–23)
* Be united with other Christians (15:1–13)
8. Conclusion (15:14–16:27)
* Paul describes his mission (15:14–21)
* Paul’s travel plans (15:22–33)

Some translations set each line of poetry farther to the right than the rest of the text to make it easier to read. The ULT does this with verses 9-11 and 21 of this chapter, which are words from the Old Testament.

Some translations set prose quotations from the Old Testament farther to the right on the page to make it easier to read. The ULT does this with the quoted words in verse 12.

In [Romans 15:14](../rom/15/14.md), Paul begins to speak more personally. He shifts from teaching to telling of his personal plans.

## Important figures of speech in this chapter

### Strong/Weak

These terms are used to refer to people who are mature and immature in their faith. Paul teaches that those who are strong in faith need to help those who are weak in faith. (See: [[rc://en/tw/dict/bible/kt/faith]])

OccurrenceNote: Alternate translation: “let … praise the Lord”

OccurrenceNote: **Jesse** was the physical father of King David. Alternate translation: “descendant of Jesse” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

GLQuote: in him the Gentiles will have hope
OccurrenceNote: Here, **him** refers to the descendant of Jesse, the Messiah. Those who are not Jews will also trust him to fulfill his promises. Alternate translation: “the people who are not Jews can trust him to do what he has promised” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

OrigQuote: πληρώσαι ὑμᾶς πάσης χαρᾶς καὶ εἰρήνης
GLQuote: May fill you with all joy and peace
OccurrenceNote: Paul exaggerates here to emphasize his point. Alternate translation: “may … fill you with great joy and peace” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])

GLQuote: Connecting Statement:
OccurrenceNote: Paul reminds the believers in Rome that God chose him to reach the Gentiles.

OrigQuote: πέπεισμαι…ἀδελφοί μου, καὶ αὐτὸς ἐγὼ περὶ ὑμῶν
GLQuote: I myself am also convinced about you, my brothers
OccurrenceNote: Paul is quite sure that the believers in Rome are honoring each other in their behavior. Alternate translation: “I myself am completely sure that you yourselves have acted toward others in a completely good way” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

GLQuote: brothers
OccurrenceNote: Here, **brothers** refers to fellow Christians, including both men and women.

GLQuote: filled with all knowledge
OccurrenceNote: Paul exaggerates here to emphasize his point. Alternate translation: “having been filled with sufficient knowledge to follow God” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])

GLQuote: able to also exhort one another
OccurrenceNote: Here, to **exhort** means to teach. Alternate translation: “also able to teach each other” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

OrigQuote: τὴν χάριν τὴν δοθεῖσάν μοι ὑπὸ τοῦ Θεοῦ
GLQuote: the grace given me by God
OccurrenceNote: Paul speaks of **grace** as if it were a physical gift that **God** had **given** him. God had appointed Paul and apostle even though he had persecuted believers before he decided to follow Jesus. You can translate this in an active form. Alternate translation: “the grace that God gave me” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

OrigQuote: γένηται ἡ προσφορὰ τῶν ἐθνῶν εὐπρόσδεκτος
GLQuote: the offering of the Gentiles might become acceptable
OccurrenceNote: Paul speaks of his preaching the gospel as if he, as a priest, were making an **offering** to God. Alternate translation: “the Gentiles might please God when they obey him” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

OrigQuote: οὐ γὰρ τολμήσω τι λαλεῖν, ὧν οὐ κατειργάσατο Χριστὸς δι’ ἐμοῦ, εἰς ὑπακοὴν ἐθνῶν λόγῳ καὶ ἔργῳ
GLQuote: by the power of signs and wonders, and by the power of the Spirit of God
OccurrenceNote: You can translate this double negative in a positive form. Alternate translation: “For the sake of the obedience of the Gentiles, I will only speak of what Christ has accomplished through me in my words and actions and by the power of signs and wonders through the power of the Holy Spirit” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublenegatives]])

GLQuote: for the obedience of the Gentiles
OccurrenceNote: Alternate translation: “so that the Gentiles will obey God”

GLQuote: These are things done by word and action
OccurrenceNote: Here, **word and deed** refers to what Christ has accomplished through Paul. Alternate translation: “through me in my words and actions” or “the things that Christ has accomplished through what I have said and done” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

GLQuote: signs and wonders
OccurrenceNote: These two words mean basically the same thing and refer to various kinds of miracles. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])

OrigQuote: ὥστε…ἀπὸ Ἰερουσαλὴμ καὶ κύκλῳ μέχρι τοῦ Ἰλλυρικοῦ
GLQuote: so that from Jerusalem, and round about as far as Illyricum
OccurrenceNote: This is from the city of **Jerusalem** as far as the province of **Illyricum**, a region close to Italy.

OrigQuote: οὕτως δὲ φιλοτιμούμενον εὐαγγελίζεσθαι, οὐχ ὅπου ὠνομάσθη Χριστός
GLQuote: In this way, my desire has been to proclaim the gospel, but not where Christ is known by name
OccurrenceNote: Paul only wants to preach to people who have never heard of Christ. Alternate translation: “but because of this, I want to preach the good news in places where people have never heard of Christ” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

OrigQuote: ἵνα μὴ ἐπ’ ἀλλότριον θεμέλιον οἰκοδομῶ
GLQuote: in order that I might not build upon another man’s foundation
OccurrenceNote: Paul speaks of his ministry work as if he were building a house on a **foundation**. Alternate translation: “in order that I might not be simply continuing the work that someone else already started. I do not want to be like a man who builds a house on someone else’s foundation” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

GLQuote: It is as it is written
OccurrenceNote: Here Paul refers to what Isaiah wrote in the scriptures. You can make the meaning explicit. Alternate translation: “what is happening is like what was written by Isaiah in the scriptures” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

You can translate this in an active form and make the meaning explicit. Alternate translation: “what is happening is like what Isaiah wrote in the scriptures” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

GLQuote: Those to whom no tidings of him came
OccurrenceNote: You can translate this in active form. Alternate translation: “Those whom no one had told the news about him” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

GLQuote: Connecting Statement:
OccurrenceNote: Paul tells the believers in Rome about his personal plans to visit them and asks the believers to pray.

GLQuote: I was also hindered
OccurrenceNote: You can translate this in an active form. Alternate translation: “they also hindered me” or “people also hindered me” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

OrigQuote: μηκέτι τόπον ἔχων ἐν τοῖς κλίμασι τούτοις
GLQuote: I no longer have any place in these regions
OccurrenceNote: Paul implies that there are no more places in these areas where people live who have not heard about Christ. Alternate translation: “there are no more places in these regions where people have not heard about Christ” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

GLQuote: Spain
OccurrenceNote: At that time, **Spain** was a Roman province west of Rome that Paul desired to visit. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

GLQuote: in passing
OccurrenceNote: Alternate translation: “as I pass through Rome” or “while I am on my way”

GLQuote: and to be helped by you along my journey there
OccurrenceNote: Here Paul implies that he wants the Roman believers to provide some financial assistance to him for his journey to Spain. Alternate translation: “that you will provide for me on my journey” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
You can translate this in active form. Alternate translation: “and that you will help me on my journey” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

OrigQuote: ἐὰν ὑμῶν πρῶτον ἀπὸ μέρους ἐμπλησθῶ
GLQuote: I have enjoyed your company
OccurrenceNote: Alternate translation: “after I have enjoyed spending some time with you”

GLQuote: it was the good pleasure of Macedonia and Achaia
OccurrenceNote: Here the words **Macedonia** and **Achaia** are synecdoches for the people who live in those areas. Alternate translation: “the believers in the provinces of Macedonia and Achaia were happy” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

GLQuote: Indeed they were please to do this
OccurrenceNote: Alternate translation: “Indeed, the believers in Macedonia and Achaia were pleased to do it”

GLQuote: indeed, they are their debtors
OccurrenceNote: Alternate translation: “indeed the people of Macedonia and Achaia are in debt to the believers in Jerusalem”

OrigQuote: εἰ…τοῖς πνευματικοῖς αὐτῶν ἐκοινώνησαν τὰ ἔθνη, ὀφείλουσιν καὶ ἐν τοῖς σαρκικοῖς λειτουργῆσαι αὐτοῖς
GLQuote: if the Gentiles have shared in their spiritual things, they owe it to them also to serve them
OccurrenceNote: Alternate translation: “since the Gentiles have shared in the spiritual things of the Jerusalem believers, the Gentiles ought to share their physical things with the Jerusalem believers”

GLQuote: made sure that they have received what was collected
OccurrenceNote: Paul speaks of the money he is taking to Jerusalem as if it were a **fruit** that was collected and **sealed** for them. Alternate translation: “and have safely delivered this offering to them” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

GLQuote: I know that when I come to you I will come in the fullness of the blessing of Christ
OccurrenceNote: This phrase means that Christ will bless Paul and the Roman believers. Alternate translation: “Christ will abundantly bless us” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

GLQuote: Now
OccurrenceNote: If your language has a way to show that Paul has stopped talking about the good things he is confident of ([Romans 15:29](../15/29.md)) and is now starting to talk about the dangers he faces, use it here.

GLQuote: I urge you
OccurrenceNote: Alternate translation: “I encourage you”

GLQuote: brothers
OccurrenceNote: Here, **brothers** refers to fellow Christians, including both men and women.

GLQuote: to strive together with
OccurrenceNote: Alternate translation: “to work hard with” or “to struggle with”

GLQuote: I may be rescued from those who are disobedient
OccurrenceNote: You can state this in active form. Alternate translation: “God may rescue me from those who are disobedient” or “God may keep those who are disobedient from harming me” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

OrigQuote: καὶ ἡ διακονία μου ἡ εἰς Ἰερουσαλὴμ εὐπρόσδεκτος τοῖς ἁγίοις γένηται
GLQuote: and that my service for Jerusalem may be acceptable to the believers
OccurrenceNote: Here Paul expresses his desire that the **saints** in **Jerusalem** will gladly accept the money from the believers in Macedonia and Achaia. Alternate translation: “and pray that the believers in Jerusalem will be glad to receive the money that I am bringing them” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

GLQuote: May the God of peace be with
OccurrenceNote: The **God of peace** means the God who causes believers to have inner peace. Alternate translation: “I pray that God who causes all of us to have inner peace may be with” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

# Romans 16 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

8. Conclusion (15:14–16:27)
* Paul describes his mission (15:14–21)
* Paul’s travel plans (15:22–33)
* Paul commends Phoebe (16:1–2)
* Paul greets Christians in Rome (16:3–16)
* Paul warns against false teachers (16:17–20)
* Paul greets more Christians in Rome (16:21–24)
* Doxology (16:25–27)

In this chapter, Paul gives personal greetings to some of the Christians in Rome. It was common to end a letter in the ancient Near East with this type of personal greeting.

## Other possible translation difficulties in this chapter

Because of the personal nature of this chapter, much of the context is unknown. This will make translation more difficult. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

GLQuote: Connecting Statement:
OccurrenceNote: Paul then greets many of the believers in Rome by name.

GLQuote: I commend to you Phoebe
OccurrenceNote: Alternate translation: “I want you to respect Phoebe”

GLQuote: Phoebe
OccurrenceNote: **Phoebe** is a woman’s name. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

GLQuote: our sister
OccurrenceNote: The word **our** refers to Paul and all believers. Alternate translation: “our sister in Christ” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-exclusive]])

GLQuote: Cenchrea
OccurrenceNote: **Cenchrea** was a seaport city in Greece. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

GLQuote: you may receive her in the Lord
OccurrenceNote: Paul encourages the Roman believers to welcome Phoebe as a fellow believer. Alternate translation: “you would welcome her because we all belong to the Lord” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

GLQuote: in a manner worthy of the saints
OccurrenceNote: Alternate translation: “in the way that believers should welcome other believers”

GLQuote: stand by her
OccurrenceNote: Paul encourages the Roman believers to give to Phoebe anything she needs. Alternate translation: “help her” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])

OrigQuote: καὶ…προστάτις πολλῶν ἐγενήθη καὶ ἐμοῦ αὐτοῦ
GLQuote: has become a helper of many, and of myself as well
OccurrenceNote: Alternate translation: “has helped many people, and she has also helped me”

GLQuote: Priscilla and Aquila
OccurrenceNote: **Priscilla** was the wife of **Aquila**. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

OrigQuote: τοὺς συνεργούς μου ἐν Χριστῷ Ἰησοῦ
GLQuote: my fellow workers in Christ Jesus
OccurrenceNote: Paul’s **fellow workers** are people who also tell others about Jesus. Alternate translation: “who work with me to tell people about Christ Jesus” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

OrigQuote: καὶ τὴν κατ’ οἶκον αὐτῶν ἐκκλησίαν
GLQuote: Greet the church that is in their house
OccurrenceNote: Alternate translation: “and greet the believers who meet in their house to worship”

GLQuote: Epaenetus
OccurrenceNote: **Epaenetus** is the name of a man. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

GLQuote: firstfruit of Asia to Christ
OccurrenceNote: Paul speaks of Epaenetus as if he were a fruit that he harvested. Alternate translation: “first person in Asia to believe in Jesus” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

GLQuote: Mary
OccurrenceNote: **Mary** is a woman’s name. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

GLQuote: Andronicus
OccurrenceNote: **Andronicus** is a man’s name. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

GLQuote: Junias
OccurrenceNote: This could refer to: (1) Junia, a woman’s name. (2) Junias, a man’s name, although this is less likely. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

OrigQuote: οἵτινές εἰσιν ἐπίσημοι ἐν τοῖς ἀποστόλοις
GLQuote: They are prominent among the apostles
OccurrenceNote: You can translate this in an active form. Alternate translation: “whom the apostles know very well” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

GLQuote: Ampliatus
OccurrenceNote: **Ampliatus** is a man’s name. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

GLQuote: my beloved in the Lord
OccurrenceNote: Alternate translation: “my dear friend and fellow believer in the Lord”

GLQuote: Urbanus … Stachys
OccurrenceNote: These are the names of men. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

GLQuote: Apelles … Aristobulus
OccurrenceNote: These are the names of men. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

GLQuote: the approved in Christ
OccurrenceNote: The word **approved** refers to someone who has been tested and proved to be genuine. Alternate translation: “whom Christ has approved”

GLQuote: Herodion … Narcissus
OccurrenceNote: These are the names of men. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

GLQuote: who are in the Lord
OccurrenceNote: This refers to those who trust in Jesus. Alternate translation: “who are believers” or “who belong to the Lord” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

GLQuote: Tryphaena … Tryphosa … Persis
OccurrenceNote: These are women’s names. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

GLQuote: Rufus
OccurrenceNote: **Rufus** is a man’s name. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

GLQuote: chosen in the Lord
OccurrenceNote: You can translate this in an active form. Alternate translation: “whom the Lord has chosen” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

GLQuote: his mother and mine
OccurrenceNote: Paul speaks of the mother of Rufus as if she were his own **mother**. Alternate translation: “his mother, whom I also think of as my mother” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

GLQuote: Asyncritus … Phlegon … Hermes … Patrobas … Hermas
OccurrenceNote: These are names of men. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

GLQuote: brothers
OccurrenceNote: Here, **brothers** refers to fellow Christians, including both men and women.

GLQuote: Philologus … Nereus … Olympas
OccurrenceNote: These are names of men. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

GLQuote: Julia
OccurrenceNote: **Julia** is the name of a woman. She was probably the wife of Philologus. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

GLQuote: a holy kiss
OccurrenceNote: an expression of affection for fellow believers

OrigQuote: ἀσπάζονται ὑμᾶς αἱ ἐκκλησίαι πᾶσαι τοῦ Χριστοῦ
GLQuote: All the churches of Christ greet you
OccurrenceNote: Here Paul speaks in a general manner concerning the **churches** of Christ. Alternate translation: “The believers in all the churches in this area send their greetings to you” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])

GLQuote: Connecting Statement:
OccurrenceNote: Paul gives one last warning to the believers about unity and living for God.

GLQuote: brothers
OccurrenceNote: Here, **brothers** refers to fellow Christians, including both men and women.

GLQuote: to think about
OccurrenceNote: Alternate translation: “to watch out for”

GLQuote: who are causing the divisions and obstacles
OccurrenceNote: This refers to those who argue and cause others to stop trusting in Jesus. Alternate translation: “who are causing believers to argue with one another and to stop having faith in God” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

OrigQuote: παρὰ τὴν διδαχὴν ἣν ὑμεῖς ἐμάθετε
GLQuote: They are going beyond the teaching that you have learned
OccurrenceNote: Alternate translation: “and teaching things that do not agree with the truth you have already learned”

GLQuote: Turn away from them
OccurrenceNote: Here, **turn away** is a metaphor for “refuse to listen.” Alternate translation: “do not listen to them” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

GLQuote: but their own stomach
OccurrenceNote: The words “they serve” are understood from the previous phrase. Alternate translation: “but they serve their own stomach” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])

GLQuote: but their own stomach
OccurrenceNote: Here, **stomach** is a metonym that refers to physical desires. Alternate translation: “but they only care about their physical desires” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
Serving there **stomach** represents satisfying their desires. Alternate translation: “but they only want to satisfy their own selfish desires” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

OrigQuote: καὶ διὰ τῆς χρηστολογίας καὶ εὐλογίας
GLQuote: By their smooth and flattering speech
OccurrenceNote: The words **smooth** and **flattering** mean basically the same thing. Paul is emphasizing how these people are deceiving believers. Alternate translation: “and by saying things that seem to be good and true” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])

GLQuote: they deceive the hearts of the innocent
OccurrenceNote: Here, **hearts** is a metonym for a person’s mind or inner being. Alternate translation: “they deceive the innocent believers” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

GLQuote: innocent
OccurrenceNote: This refers to those who are simple, inexperienced, and naive. Alternate translation: “of those who innocently trust them” or “of those who do not know these teachers are fooling them”

OrigQuote: ἡ γὰρ ὑμῶν ὑπακοὴ, εἰς πάντας ἀφίκετο
GLQuote: For your obedience reaches everyone
OccurrenceNote: Here Paul speaks of the Roman believers’ **obedience** as if it were a person who could go to people. Alternate translation: “For everyone has heard how you obey Jesus” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

GLQuote: innocent to that which is evil
OccurrenceNote: Alternate translation: “not involved in doing evil things”

OrigQuote: ὁ δὲ Θεὸς τῆς εἰρήνης συντρίψει τὸν Σατανᾶν ὑπὸ τοὺς πόδας ὑμῶν ἐν τάχει
GLQuote: The God of peace will soon crush Satan under your feet
OccurrenceNote: The phrase **crush … under your feet** refers to complete victory over an enemy. Here Paul speaks of the victory over **Satan** as if the Roman believers were trampling an enemy under their **feet**. Alternate translation: “Soon God will give you peace and complete victory over Satan” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

GLQuote: Connecting Statement:
OccurrenceNote: Paul gives greetings from the believers who are with him.

GLQuote: Lucius, Jason, and Sosipater
OccurrenceNote: These are names of men. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

OrigQuote: ἐγὼ, Τέρτιος, ὁ γράψας τὴν ἐπιστολὴν
GLQuote: Tertius, who write this epistle
OccurrenceNote: **Tertius** is the man who wrote down what Paul spoke. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

GLQuote: greet you in the Lord
OccurrenceNote: Alternate translation: “greet you as a fellow believer”

GLQuote: Gaius … Erastus … Quartus
OccurrenceNote: These are names of men. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

GLQuote: the host
OccurrenceNote: This refers to Gaius, the person in whose house Paul and his fellow believers gathered for worship.

GLQuote: the treasurer
OccurrenceNote: This is a person who takes care of the money for a group.

GLQuote: Connecting Statement:
OccurrenceNote: Paul closes with a prayer of blessing.

GLQuote: Now
OccurrenceNote: Here the word **Now** marks the closing section of the letter. If you have a way of doing this in your language, you can use it here.

GLQuote: to strengthen you
OccurrenceNote: Paul speaks here of having strong faith as if a person were being set firmly in place. Alternate translation: “to make your faith strong” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

OrigQuote: κατὰ τὸ εὐαγγέλιόν μου, καὶ τὸ κήρυγμα Ἰησοῦ Χριστοῦ
GLQuote: according to my gospel and the preaching of Jesus Christ
OccurrenceNote: Alternate translation: “by the good news that I have preached about Jesus Christ”

OrigQuote: κατὰ ἀποκάλυψιν μυστηρίου χρόνοις αἰωνίοις σεσιγημένου
GLQuote: according to the revelation of the mystery that had been kept secret for long ages
OccurrenceNote: Paul says that God has revealed previously hidden truths to the believers. He speaks of these truths as if they were a **secret**. Alternate translation: “because God has revealed to us believers what had been kept secret for a long time” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

OrigQuote: κατὰ ἀποκάλυψιν μυστηρίου χρόνοις αἰωνίοις σεσιγημένου
OccurrenceNote: You can translate this in an active form. Alternate translation: “because God has revealed to us believers the secret that he was keeping for a long time” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

OrigQuote: φανερωθέντος δὲ νῦν διά τε Γραφῶν προφητικῶν, κατ’ ἐπιταγὴν τοῦ αἰωνίου Θεοῦ εἰς ὑπακοὴν πίστεως, εἰς πάντα τὰ ἔθνη γνωρισθέντος
GLQuote: but now has been revealed and made known through the prophetic writings to all nations, by the command of the eternal God
OccurrenceNote: The verbs **revealed** and **made known** mean basically the same thing. Paul uses both of them to emphasize his point. Alternate translation: “but now the mystery has been made known to all the nations through the prophetic writings so people can believe” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])

OrigQuote: φανερωθέντος δὲ νῦν διά τε Γραφῶν προφητικῶν, κατ’ ἐπιταγὴν τοῦ αἰωνίου Θεοῦ εἰς ὑπακοὴν πίστεως, εἰς πάντα τὰ ἔθνη γνωρισθέντος
OccurrenceNote: You can combine the verbs **revealed** and **made known** in an active form. Alternate translation: “but now the eternal God has made it known to all the nations through the prophetic writings so that people would believe” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

GLQuote: to bring about the obedience of faith
OccurrenceNote: Here, **obedience** and **faith** are abstract nouns. You can use the verbs “obey” and “trust” in your translation. Alternate translation: “so that all nations will believe and obey” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
You may need to make explicit who will obey and trust. Alternate translation: “so that all nations will obey God because they trust in him” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

OrigQuote: μόνῳ σοφῷ Θεῷ διὰ Ἰησοῦ Χριστοῦ, ᾧ ἡ δόξα εἰς τοὺς αἰῶνας. ἀμήν!
GLQuote: To the only wise God … be glory forever. Amen
OccurrenceNote: Here, **through Jesus Christ** refers to what Jesus did. To give **glory** means to praise God. Alternate translation: “Because of what Jesus Christ has done for us, we will praise forever the one who alone is God and who alone is wise. Amen!” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
